thread.title: Unelected peers could delay Brexit by up to a YEAR as House of Lords fumes over 'rubber stamping'
thread.title_full: Unelected peers could delay Brexit by up to a YEAR as House of Lords fumes over 'rubber stamping' - Mirror Online

author: mirror.co.uk
title: Unelected peers could delay Brexit by up to a YEAR as House of Lords fumes over 'rubber stamping'
text:
Unelected peers could delay Brexit by up to a YEAR as House of Lords fumes over 'rubber stamping' All 104 Lib Dem peers will vote against Article 50 and it would take only 30 Tories to do the same for Theresa May’s schedule to be sunk Share Comments By Nigel Nelson 11:04, 5 FEB 2017 Updated 11:13, 5 FEB 2017 News Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch this video again Video will play in The moment MPs voted to back Article 50 bill Share this video Watch Next politics Angry peers could delay Theresa May’s Brexit timetable by up to a year.
The PM wants to trigger Article 50, starting the process of leaving the EU, by the end of March.
But she needs the agreement of the Lords as well as the Commons to do it.
And Tory, Lib Dem and Labour peers are up in arms over the lack of time they are being given to scrutinise her proposals. All 104 Lib Dem peers will vote against Article 50 and it would take only 30 Tories to do the same for Mrs May’s schedule to be sunk.
If the Lords refuse to pass Article 50 they will be hit with the Parliament Act, which forces legislation through.
Lording it over the public desire for Brexit? (Photo: Getty) Lib Dem leader Tim Farron - all of his party's peers are expected to vote against the bill (Photo: Chris J Ratcliffe) But that cannot be imposed until a year of wrangling has taken place.
Tory peer Baroness Altmann, a former pensions minister, said she respects the supremacy of the Commons in voting through Article 50.
But she warned that many peers are unhappy at the way ­Parliament is being railroaded into rubber-stamping it. She said: “I don’t understand why the March 31 deadline is so significant when this is such a monumental decision.”
A detail is seen from a copy of the Brexit Article 50 bill (Photo: REUTERS) Lib Dem leader Tim Farron said: “Many Tories recognise leaving the single market threatens jobs and growth.
“They should join us in challenging it in the Lords.”
Labour Lords leader Angela Smith vowed the issue would be fully scrutinised despite the “truncated ­timetable imposed by the Government”.
